docs.lead_paragraph: What happens when a flagship product becomes an afterthought? At Intuit, that was happening with Quicken, the very brand that made it a software powerhouse in the 1980's and 1990's. Even Stephen M. Bennett, a former General Electric executive and acolyte of Jack Welch, ignored it after he arrived in 2000. Quicken's revenue was flat or declining while its other major products, TurboTax and QuickBooks, produced robust growth. ''Quicken wasn't on my radar,'' Mr. Bennett recalled in a recent interview.

headline.main: It's a Quicken World Again; Intuit Unit Charges Back, With Products Like a Medical Bill Manager

docs.snippet: Intuit is making a comeback, pushing beyond personal finance with new products for managing medical bills and investment properties.

docs.lead_paragraph: ON his first visit to Canyon Ranch in Tucson in the 1980's, Steve Akin went for a walk each morning among the giant saguaro cactuses in the quiet desert canyons surrounding the spa. In the afternoon, he had a massage, took a dip in the pool or explored his spiritual side in a meditative yoga class. A lot has changed since then. Now when Mr. Akin, a 60-year-old financial executive, makes his annual visit to Canyon Ranch's property in Lenox, Mass., he dons an oxygen mask, has a bunch of wires strapped to his chest and jogs on a treadmill so a doctor can measure his breathing and heart rate. Later, he will most likely have a bone density scan, a lipid analysis and an electrocardiogram.

headline.main: The Spa Experience: Mud Bath, Massage, M.R.I.

docs.snippet: At some of the country's largest spa resorts, massages and yoga classes are being supplemented by bone density scans, electrocardiograms and stress tests.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki's office said last night that he was inclined to veto a key provision of the New York City transit contract settlement announced this week -- one that gives 20,000 workers refunds of pension contributions -- noting that he had vetoed a similar provision twice before. The provision, which would require a change in state law, would give many workers refunds of payments they made to their pension plan between 1994 and 2001, when most workers contributed 5.3 percent of their earnings. In 2001, the contribution for most workers was reduced to 2 percent.

headline.main: Pataki May Veto Pension Refunds In Transit Pact

docs.snippet: A key provision of the New York City transit contract settlement gives 20,000 workers refunds of pension contributions.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the Sunday before Christmas, Amy Schultz sat on the bed in her apartment in Kingston, N.Y., and pulled a strawberry blond wig off her head. ''It gets so hot,'' she said, exposing patches of soft gray hair. The long blond locks she spent years growing were gone, taken by months of chemotherapy to fight three kinds of cancer detected nine months ago.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Afflicted, Yet Looking on the Bright Side

docs.snippet: On the Sunday before Christmas, Amy Schultz sat on the bed in her apartment in Kingston, N.Y., and pulled a strawberry blond wig off her head.      ''It gets so hot,'' she said, exposing patches of soft gray hair. The long blond locks she spent years...

docs.lead_paragraph: While Catherine Raney gleefully talked about her American record in the long-track speedskating national championships at the Utah Olympic Oval this week, she wore her conflicting loyalties on her sleeves -- literally. Adorning each arm of her warm-up suit was a Canadian maple leaf. Although Raney will represent the United States in her third Olympics and is American to the core, she chooses to train outside of U.S. Speedskating's national team, and lives instead in Calgary, Alberta. Forgoing the coaching and ice time she would receive free here, she pays up to $18,000 a year, working with Canadian coaches and Canadian skaters.
docs.abstract: US Olympic contender Catherine Raney is among a number of American speedskaters who choose not to train with US team, and instead live and train in Canada; photo (M1
docs.snippet: More than half of the top American long-track speedskaters have abandoned the national team, giving up its financial support in favor of going their own way.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the measure of a fair labor contract is stereo sounds of griping, things worked out reasonably for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its unionized employees. Still, it should not be lost on the 33,700 workers who walked off the job, breaking New York State law in the process, that they wound up with a contract not terribly different than what was on the table before the walkout. This was a strike that never needed to happen, and we hope that message reverberates in the future. In the end, the union got raises totaling up to 11 percent over three years and an extra holiday, and fought back an attempt to raise the retirement age of 55 for new workers. In exchange for taking pension changes off the table, workers will have to pay 1.5 percent of their pay toward health insurance premiums. That will save the transportation authority just $32 million a year, but it at least begins to address the stampeding increases in health care costs for state workers.

headline.main: A Pact New York Can Ride On

docs.snippet: The transit strike against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority never needed to happen, and we hope that message reverberates in the future.

docs.lead_paragraph: He was excoriated on tabloid front pages and by the mayor and governor. As thousands streamed across the Brooklyn Bridge on a frigid night during last week's transit strike, someone in a car yelled out his name, prefacing it with a curse. But now, a day after details of an agreement between the transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were spelled out, Roger Toussaint, the union's president, seems to have emerged in a far better position than seemed likely just a few days ago.

headline.main: Pull of Union In Transit Pact

docs.snippet: If there is a real winner in the walkout that hobbled the city, it is the workers who went out on strike, and their leader.
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The husband and wife now say they have only one functioning brain between them. In April 2004, a stroke robbed Julie Shaffer, a former English professor, of her ability to express words and numbers. Thoughts are bottlenecked in her brain -- expressed with sentence fragments and flailing fingers.

headline.main: Wanted: Patience of Job and Kindness of Strangers

docs.lead_paragraph: A truly great city inspires truly great dreams, even during the days when all else seems lost. There was no bleaker time in New York's history than 9/11. Yet it was then, with the restaurant where he had worked for six years -- Windows on the World -- in splinters and 73 of his fellow employees gone, that Silverio Moog's dream started to take shape.
docs.snippet: Former employees of Windows on the World have formed a cooperative that will run one of New York City's first worker-owned restaurants.
